q: What are the symptoms of necrotising fasciitis?
a: Symptoms of necrotising fasciitis can include intense pain or loss of feeling near a cut or wound, swelling of the skin around the affected area, flu-like symptoms, and black, purple, or grey blotches and blisters on the skin.

q: When should I seek immediate medical help for necrotising fasciitis?
a: You should call 999 or go to A&E if you have a cut or wound that is much more painful than expected, experience symptoms like a high temperature, headache, tiredness, and muscle aches, have sudden confusion, or notice black, purple, or grey blotches or blisters near a cut or wound.

q: Where can I find my nearest A&E to seek help for necrotising fasciitis?
a: You can find your nearest A&E by using the NHS website or by calling 999.

q: What should I do if I am not sure what to do about necrotising fasciitis?
a: If you are unsure about what to do, you can call NHS 111 or get help from 111 online. They will be able to guide you to the right place for assistance.

q: What are the treatments for necrotising fasciitis?
a: Treatment for necrotising fasciitis usually includes antibiotics and surgery to remove the affected area. In some cases, amputation of affected limbs may be necessary. Further surgery and physiotherapy might be needed for recovery.

q: Are there any long-term changes after treating necrotising fasciitis?
a: After successful treatment of necrotising fasciitis, there may be long-term changes in how your body looks and how you move or use the affected part of your body.

q: How does necrotising fasciitis occur?
a: Necrotising fasciitis is caused by an infection that enters the body through wounds, such as cuts, burns, insect bites, surgery, or injecting drugs. People with diabetes or a weakened immune system are at a higher risk.

q: What are the common ways necrotising fasciitis enters the body?
a: Necrotising fasciitis can enter the body through cuts, scratches, burns, scalds, insect bites, surgery, or injecting drugs.

q: Who is at a higher risk of developing necrotising fasciitis?
a: People with diabetes or a weakened immune system are more at risk of developing necrotising fasciitis.

q: What are the similarities between necrotising fasciitis and cellulitis?
a: The symptoms of necrotising fasciitis are similar to more common skin infections like cellulitis.

q: What are the differences between necrotising fasciitis and cellulitis?
a: One major difference between necrotising fasciitis and cellulitis is that necrotising fasciitis is a rare and life-threatening infection, while cellulitis is a more common skin infection.
